title: Structures: Organizing Data
description: Create custom data types using structures to group related variables

concepts.title: Understanding Structures
concepts.content:
A structure is a user-defined data type that groups multiple variables of different types together. Unlike arrays, which hold elements of the same type, structures can combine different types‚Äîintegers, floats, characters, strings, and even other structures.

You define a structure using the struct keyword: struct Person { int age; float height; char initial; };. This creates a new type called Person. Inside the curly braces, you declare the members (or fields) of the structure‚Äîthe variables that make up the structure.

Once you've defined a structure type, you can declare variables of that type: struct Person person1;. This creates a variable person1 of type struct Person, which contains all the members you defined.

To access members of a structure, you use the dot operator: person1.age = 25; sets the age member, and printf("%d\n", person1.age); prints it.

You can initialize a structure when you declare it: struct Person person1 = {25, 5.9, 'A'};. The values are assigned to members in order.

Structures are useful for creating meaningful groupings of related data. Instead of having separate variables age, height, and initial scattered throughout your code, you group them in a Person structure, making your code more organized and readable.

concepts.title: Arrays of Structures
concepts.content:
Just like you can have arrays of integers or arrays of characters, you can have arrays of structures. This is incredibly useful for managing collections of related objects.

To declare an array of structures: struct Person people[3]; creates an array of 3 Person structures. Each element in the array is a complete structure with all its members.

To access members of a structure in an array, you combine array indexing with the dot operator: people[0].age = 25; sets the age member of the first person.

You can iterate through arrays of structures using loops, processing each structure one at a time. This pattern is used constantly in real programs for managing lists of employees, students, inventory items, and any other entities.

Arrays of structures are powerful because they let you manage groups of objects efficiently. Instead of having separate arrays for ages, heights, and initials, you have one array of Person structures where each element contains all the information about one person.

concepts.title: Passing Structures to Functions
concepts.content:
You can pass structures to functions just like any other data type. This allows you to write functions that operate on structures.

You can pass a structure by value: void printPerson(struct Person p) { printf("%d\n", p.age); };. This passes a copy of the structure, so changes inside the function don't affect the original.

You can also pass a structure by pointer: void setPerson(struct Person *p, int age) { p->age = age; };. When passing by pointer, you use the arrow operator (->) instead of the dot operator to access members. This is more efficient for large structures because you're only passing an address rather than copying the entire structure.

Functions can return structures: struct Person createPerson(int age, float height) { struct Person p; p.age = age; p.height = height; return p; };. This allows functions to construct and return structures.

Understanding how to use structures with functions is important for writing modular, organized code. Functions that work with structures encapsulate operations on those structures, making your code more maintainable.
